page.title: 15FARMING in SACOMBE cont.
page.content: The young birds can get gapes, a disease in which worms develop in the trachia making breathing difficult. This is avoided by completely cleaning out their sheds and disinfecting every ten weeks. When the pheasants are released some go to areas where there are no pheasants. This is good because in the wild the birds do not breed successfully. They are disturbed mostly by people or dogs. Also modern farming has removed the insects that would be the food for the young. The Keeper is always asking walkers to be quiet and explaining why. During the season they hope to shoot 50% of the birds. Each time they hold a shoot ten guns are used, mostly by members of the London-based group. The price for last season's birds, if sold, was three pounds a brace. The cost of producing them was ten pounds.
